div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.– Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber's address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum.

ADVERTISEMENTS.– P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20, every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news columns P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
N.B.– Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices: 86, New Broad-street, E.C.
THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE” IS PRINTED ON PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS Co., LIMITED (SALES OFFICE: 27, CANNON STREET, E.C.) 36-4

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
FRIDAY, JANUARY 27, 1905.

div.head: RUSSIA'S NEW DODGE.
div.p: We have at last reached a stage in the war when we have to take into our calculations the probable effect on its future development of Russian desperation. The deliberate violation of Chinese neutrality by the cavalry of Mischenko, together with the threats contained in the recent Note to Peking and the Powers charging China with affording assist ance to Japan, are full of ominous significance. Puerile and fictitious as these charges are they have been made with deliberate purpose, and the more they are considered the greater reason there appears for the apprehension that the Russian Government is preparing for a step which will merge the present issue between herself and Japan into a chaos of fresh complications. The acceptance by the two belligerents in February last of the American Note defining the Liao River as the inviolable western boundary of the theatre of war has until Mischenko's raid been strictly - adhered to. Now, however, Russia has of set purpose broken through this agreement, and her Note complaining of belligerent acts on the part of China is intended as her excuse, and will be made the pretext for further violations of Chinese territory as soon as ever it suits her purpose. This Russian mood is born of despair, and it will probably only need another serious deleat on the Sha-ho, to bring about its full development in the shape of a hostile incursion into Chinese territory to the west of the Liao, or more probably an attack by way of Turkestan or the Goui towards Peking, if pressed beyond the Hun-ho by the Japanese.

The westward extension of the belligerent area towards the Chinese border will lessen the Russian power of concentration as well as that of Japan. If therefore Kuropatkin is hoping by such a diversion to weaken Oyama's eastern flank, his attempt can only fail, and the sinister suggestion of the recent move is a deliberate intention on the part of St. Petersburg to force China into a belligerent position, trusting to the subsequent contusion of the international situation to enable her to avoid a fight to a humiliating finish with Japan. Russia will by this means obtain the more active assistance of France and Germany. The scheme of involving Cuina will also do more. Whereas now Russia has no legitimate raison d'être on Chinese territory in Manchuria, if China can be treated as a belligereut the intruder will at once advance combatant rights to as much as he thinks he can make good a claim to when the time of final settlement arrives. Russia's new move, therefore, looks like part of a deeplaid scheme to avoid the full consequences of impending final deteat at the hands of Japan. We have been afforded a preliminary view of its initiation. And it is probable that we shall not have to wait long for further developments.

div.head: NILE COLD STORAGE CO.
div.p: STEAM TRAWLING IN LOCAL WATERS. The Port Said works of the Cold Storage Company, Ltd, are now rapidly approaching completion. There can be no doubt that the public of Cairo anticipate with much satis faction the prospect of obtaining sufficient and regular supplies of the best meats and other produce, as imported by this company, at reasonable prices. We understand that the first consignment of meat will arrive in the course of the next few days, and comprises the finest Australian and New Zealand beef, mutton, lamb, etc., which will be on sale to the public in the New Market, Cairo, on ot before February 1.

With the object of furnishing the market with regular supplies of good fish, the company are bringing out a steam trawler, which will commence work early next mouth. It is in tended to inaugurate steam-trawling in Egyp tiau waters on a systematic basis. The success of steam-trawling in all other countries warrants the belief that it may be carried on with success here, and that it will lead to more constant supplies of fish to our markets. A steam trawler is able to go out and to return to port at all times, and in any weather. and is therefore independent of conditious which msterially restrict the operations of sailing ves sels. By this means also it is possible to reach the deeper fishing grounds, and it is expected that a much better and larger class of fish will thereby be obtained.

div.head: SITUATION IN RUSSIA. MOVEMENT CHECKED. PROCLAMATION TO WORKMEN. A RUSSIAN CALUMNY. ALLEGED ANGLO-JAPANESE INTRIGUES.

div.p: By order of the Tsar, General Trepoff and the Minister of l Finance issued issued a proclamation explaining to the workmen that they are being exploited by sell-seeking and evil-disposed persons who nave misled them in a manner rendering the intervention of an armed force inevitable. The workers forget that the Government has always been careful for their needs and is ready now, as always in the past, to listen to the just desires of the people and to satisfy them whenever possible. The workers must, however, assist the Government by the restoration of order, by returning to their work, and by boycotting the inciters of disorder. Their needs are near to the Emperor's Heart as are those of all loyal subjects, Only recently the Emeror ordered a consideration of the question of workemen's insurance, and He Has now directed the Ministry of Finance to draft a law for shortening the hours of labour, and to take measures for making it legally possible lor the working classes to discuss and make known their needs. The Government will protect all those who return to work.

The Municipality Has voted by a large majority 2,500 sterling towards the relief of the wounded and the families of the killed. A further 200 has been voted towards the improvement of the ambulance stations, in view of a repetition of the tragedy. This vote was originally coupled with a motion strongly denouncing Sunday's brutanty, which, however, the President refused to accept. (Reuter.)

The city is resuming its normal aspect. The shops are re-opening. Some troops are being withdrawn, and there is a partial resumption of work. The Government is confident that the movement has been checked, though it is resolved to continue the repressive measures.
The police yesterday posted notices in Moscow alleging that the strike movement was due to Anglo-Japanese intrigues and that the strikers were supported by British money.
A similar notice was posted at Odessa today.
Sir C. Hardinge protested against this calumny. He received assurances that measures would be taken to prevent the repetition of the publication.
The British Embassy here is guarded by sentries. (Reuter.)
A party of terrorists are marching through the streets compelling workmen to strike. The telegraph wires have been damaged(Reuter.)
At a demonstration here yesterday evening, the police attacked 5,000 workmen with swords and whips. There were a lew casualties. (R.)

div.head:
AMERICAN COTTON.
SCHEME TO REDUCE ACREAGE.

div.p: An influential Southern Cotton Convention here has adopted a scheme reducing the acreage by 25%. (Reuter.)
The Brindist Mail will close at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 3 p.m. on Monday.

div.head: Fire
div.p: During the fire, which broke out on the 22nd inst. at Debelchian village, near Kair Zayat, a large number of houses were destroyed, and two women and a child perished in the flames. The damages are estimated at L.E. 890

div.head: Suez Canal
div.p: 18 vessels passed through the Canal on the 24th inst., of which 8 were British, 4 German, 2 Dutch, 1 Italian, 1 Russian, 1 Austrian, 1 Swedish. The day's receipts amounted to frs. 515,766.56. The total amount received from 1st to 24th inst. was frs. 8,864,080.96.

div.head: Temperance
div.p: Mr. Samuel Smith, M.P., will, deliver an address on temperance and kindred subjects in the lecture-room of the American Mission, near Shepheard's Hotel, Cairo, on Saturday evening at 6 o'clock. All are invited to attend.

div.head: The Royal Visit
div.p: The arrangements during the stay in Cairo of the Duke and Duchess of Connaught have been placed in the hands of George Nungovich Bey. Nungovich Bey and Mr. Wild were at Abdeen Palace yesterday to receive the distinguished guests on their arrival.

div.head: Shepheard's
div.p: With regard to Monday's grand ball at Shepheard's, we learn that the cotillon will begin at midnight. All the invitations have already been issued, and the management have had to refuse a large number of applications for tickets, so as to obviate a crush. Tables for dinner in the restaurant or grill-room on that night should be ordered beforehand, and only persons provided with invitations will be allowed to book tables.

div.head: A Local Publication
div.p: "The Revue d'Egypte et d'Orient," in its new dress, is a considerable improvement on past numbers and shows that it is more firmiy established than ever among local publications. The January number is brimful of interesting articles written by men whose names are a guarantee of the genuine value of their contributions. We wish our little contemporary continued prosperity, and congratulate its able editors, M.M. Fernand Braun and George Vayssié.

div.head: Abbas Helmy Theatre
div.p: Signora Emma Bellincione, the great Italian opera singer, arrives at Alexandria on Monday next by the Austrian Lloyd steamer and will give a series of live performances at the above theatre. Signora Svincher, who has created such a furore in Cairo by her perfomances at the Verdi Theatre, will also give five representations at this theatre, the season beginning on Tuesday next, when the company comes down from Caire. "La Bellincione," as she is called, brings with her a lew other lights in the operatic world, and an unusual musical treat is in store for Alexandirans. Subscriptions may be booked at Messrs. Montferrato's. The following are the prices fixed for the series of ten performances : Stage boxes, L.E.60 ; first-tier boxes, L.E.30 ; second-tier boxes, L.E.22 1/2 ; orchestra stalls, L.E.3 ; stalls, L.E.2 1/4.

div.head: PASSENGER LISTS.
div.p: DEPARTURES.
Per S.S. "Seti" sailed on Wednesday for Manchester :
Mrs. Herslolf, Miss Smith, Mr. G. Hill, Mr. J. Townsend, Mr. Amhiotroi and Mr. D. Hanmanol, Mr. J. L. Lonsdale, Mr. and Mrs. Soler and infant, Mr. and Mrs. J. Jones and child.
Le paquebot "Memfi" de la Cie Florio Rubattino parti hier pour Gènes avait à bord :

Mlle Umpbebley, M. O. G. Brooke, M. B. Daniels, Mmes C. et M. Kerker, Mme. Mullins, Mme Dairs, M. L. Levin, M. G. Mattei, M. et Mme Pots, M. Vernen, M. et Mme R. Vignal, ing. et Mme Castelli, M. et Mme Perry S. Heath, M. A. P. Andrade, Mlle Ida Rosa, Père Michele, Sœur M. Colomba, M. et Mme E. Pestavino, M. et Mme Gaet. Anza, M. et Mme G. Young, M. et Mme E. V. Kellett et fils, Mme Betty Eugrinie, Sœur M. Agnès, M. F. Salvatori, et 47 passagers de 3me classe.

div.head:
THE ROYAL VISIT. ARRIVAL IN CAIRO.
THE RECEPTION AT THE STATION
div.p: At 5:20 p.m. yesterday the vice-regal train. bearing their Royal Highnesses the Duke and Duchess of Connaught, steamed into Cairo station to the sound of salutes of 21 guns from the Citadel and Abbassieh. H.H. the Kbedive and Prince Mohamed Aly, the Karl and Countess of Cromer, the Ministers and Advisers. Maj. General .Slade, C.B., Mrs. Slade, Col.

Colville and the principal officers of the Army of Occupation, Lewa Lord Edward Cecil Pasha, Kaiumkain Palmer Bey, and all the officers of the Head Quarters and District Staffs and heads of departments of the Egyptian Army,

Miralai Mansheild Pasha, etc., were waiting to receive the Royal visitors, and two guards of honor, composed of 100 N.C.O.'s and men of the 2nd Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, under Capt. Roe, and 100 N.C.O.'a and men of the 16th Egyptian Battalion, with the colours, were drawn up within the station.

The Khedive exchanged the most cordial greetings with the Duke and Duchess of Connaught, who both looked very well, and expressed his pleasure at once more meeting them in Cairo. After a similar interchange of courtesies between the Royal visitors and Lord and Lady Cromer, major-general and Mrs. Slade, and the principal members of the group of official and military dignitaries who were assembled on the platform, the Duke of Connaught made a brief inspection of the guards of honor, complimenting the Khedive and Maj.-General Slade on the fine appearance of the troops. The Royal party left the station to the strains of the National Anthem.

Thu Khedive and the Duke of Connaught then entered a State carnage and drove towards the Palace, escorted by the Cavalry of the Body Guard, and followed by the Duchess of Connaught, accompanied by Prince Mohamed Aly, and other carriages containing the duel participants in this interesting scene.

The streets were lined by large crowds and kept clear by the police, whose arrangements were excellent. British and Egyptian and other national flags were flown everywhere, the white and pale blue of the Hellenic colours being very prominent. The hotel fronts of Shepheard's and the Continental were crowded with residents amd visitors anxious to see the Khedive and his Royal guests, who graciously responded to the salutations that greeted them.

H.H. the Khedive gave a banquet of 130 covers in honor of the Duke and Duchess of Connaught at Abdeen Palace yesterday evening. Among the guests were the Princes of the Khedive family, H.R.H. Prince Gustav Adult of Sweden and Norway, the Ministers, the Earl and Countess of Cromer, the diplomatic agents, the advisors, the under-secretaries of State, Major General Slade, C.B., the heads of departments, the staff of the British Agency,
The Royal party leaves Cairo for up-river this evening under the arrangements of the Sleeping Car Company.
A very large crowd is expected to attend the races on the K. S. C. grounds this afternoon which will be graced by the presence of H.H. the Khedive and his Royal guests.

We omitted to mention in our account of the Duke and Duchess of Connaught's arrival at Alexandria yesterday that Mahmoud Pasha Sidky, Governor of Alexandria, presented a line bouquet to her Royal Highness as she landed at the Arsenal wharf, and on reaching the kiosque Miss .Muriel Murray, the pretty little laughter of M Murray Bey, Inspector of lighthouses, presented a most artistic bouquet. It was composed of purple violets, white lilac, lilies of the valley. The Duchess was very pleased with these gifts and asked for the mother of the girl to be presented to her.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive proceeded to Abdeen Palace yesterday morning amd attended midday-prayers at the Mosque of Saidna Hussein.

The receipts from the fetes on the occasion of the recent anniversary of the Khedive's accession amounted to L.E. 893, mills. 770 and the expenses to LE 841, mills. 400, which leaves a surplus of L.E. 52, mills. 370 to be carried over for next year's fete.

div.head: ARMY OF OCCUPATION.
div.p: The following officers are to take part in a staff rule ; -Major E. R. O. Ludlow, D.A.A.G, Major A. H. C Kenney Herbert, D.A.Q.M.G., Captain T. E Bayley, Staff Captain, Captain W H. Rotheram, R.E., Captain F. F. Duffus, A.S.C., and an officer, R.A.M.C. They will proceed by a train leaving Cairo at 6 a.m. on Tuesday, 31st inst., and each officer will be accompanied by his servant, his horse, and one syce.
38 N C O.'s and men of the 2nd Battalion Rife Brigade, under charge of an officer, will arrive at Cairo by the 7:20 am train on the 31st inst., from Khartoum, to await passage home.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner "Menes" sailed from Malta yesterday morning and is due hero on Sunday evening with passengers, mails, and general
The Messageries Maritimes S.S, "Salazie" arrived at Alexandria from Marseilles at 4 a.m. yesterday.
The Cunard S.S. "Tyria" arrived at Liverpool yesterday morning and the S.S. "Veria" sailed yesterday afternoon for Liverpool with a fall cargo,

div.head: EGYPT'S BANKING DEVELOPMENTS
div.p: COMPTOIR D'ESCOMPTE

The great French banking house, the Comptoir National d'Escompte, has secured the Palazzo Antoniades in Cherif Pasha street, Alexandria, as premises for its agency here. This is the only private house standing by itself in Cherif Pasha-street and it will be a magnificent site for a bank. It has been leased to the Comptoir National d Escompte for a period of ten years at a rental of L.E. 2,000 a year, including the garden and all the appurtenances of this fine mansion. The bank has also obtained the option of renewing the lease at the end of the term.

The bank intends to build on to thé garden at the back of the building and to turn the house into large and commodious banking premises. Mr. Llewelyn, who is to represent the bank as general manager for Egypt, will stay at Alexandria permanently and will take charge of all - the bank's operations in this country.
The building will bo transformed immediately and the bank will be fully installed early in the coming summer.

The Comptoir National d'Escompte has a capital of 150,000,000 francs, fully paid up, m 300,000 shares of 500 francs each. It is a Société Anonyme, which took over the business of the Comptoir d'Esoompte de Paris, which went into liquidation in 1889. The duration of the company is 50 years from 1st May, 1889. The business of the Banque de Dépôts et Comptes Courants was taken over from July, 1892, for 30,000 fully-paid shares. It is one of the greatest banks in France and on a par with the Credit Lyonnais. The directors anticipate a rapid development of business in Egypt. An agency in Cairo will be opened next year and it is probable that the bank will also extend its sphere of operations to the Sudan.

div.head: EGYPTIAN INVESTMENT AND AGENCY.
div.p: The Egyptian Investment and Agency, Limited, yesterday received the final list of subscribers in Egypt and the officials of the company are hard at work getting the allotments ready.

Over 2,450 applications for more than 3,250,000 shares were received here, and wo learn that the public will get 2-5% on most applications for above 500. Below that figure, and in a few other cases, letters of regret will have to be sent. These it is hoped to post to-night or to-morrow. The allotment letters will follow next week.

div.head: DELTA LIGHT RAILWAY CO.
div.p: The Egyptian Delta Light Railways (Limited) announces that coupons tor accumulated arrears of dividend on the 5 and 1/2 per Cent Cumulative Preference Shares to the 30th September, 1904, are now ready for issue. Share warrants to bearer and registered certificates must be lodged either at the offices of the company, 211, Gresham House, Old Broad-street, Loudon, or with the National Bank of Egypt, Cairo or Alexandria, for endorsement shares Nos. 1 to 63,324 are entitled to Coupon F for 14s. per share, less income tax ; shares Nos. 63,325 to 74,437 are entitled to Coupon G for 1s. 4d. per share, less income tax , and Shares Nos. 74,438 to 85.540 are entitled to Coupon H for Is. per share, loss income tax

div.head: THE MAHMAL THEFT.
div.p: No trace whatever has been discovered of either the money stolen from the Mahmal caravan or the thieves, and it has transpired that though it was the intention of the authorities to couple the specie van and the van containing the guard some ingenious person interposed no less than 16 other trucks. Under these circumstances it is hard to say whether the theft took place at Abbassieh or during the journey, and it has not been established that the specie van was under observation during the whole of the time that it was standing on the line at Abbassieh.

We should have thought that the simplest precaution would have been the most effectual, namely, to put a couple of soldiers with loaded rifles into the specie van ; but this plan, which is universally employed in India, never seems to have struck the responsible authorities. Meantime, £8,000 have disappeared, and as far as we can see this will figure in next year's accounts under the heading of "Unforeseen Expenditure."
provincial councils.

By Khédivial decree the Provincial Councils of Assiout, Keneh, Girgeh, Beni Souef, and Ghizeh are to meet on Sunday next at 9 am. at the Moudiriehs to take the oath and to elect delegates to the Legislative Council.

div.head: AN ALEXANDRIA SCANDAL.
div.p: This morning, the case brought by Mr. Ninci, commercial manager of the Sucreries et do la Raffinerie d'Egypte Company at Alexandria, against his wife, Mrs. Olga Ninci, nee Coustantinides, came on for hearing before the Italian Consular Court at Alexandria Mr. Ninci is asking for a separation from his wile on account of her adultery with Judge Constantine Dimaras, President of the Hellenic Consular Tribunal at Alexandria

Mr. Ninci was represented by Maître Mario Colucci and the lady by Maître Guidotti. The hearing of the case was adjourned this morning for a week on the application of Maitre Guidotti on behalf of Mrs. Ninci.
Judge Dimaras left Alexandria this morning or the Pineus by the Russian packet. News has been received from Athens that the
judge has been deprived of his official position,

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The ex-Emprees Eugénie, travelling incognito as the Countess de Pierrefond,. arrived at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, last night from Port Said.
The suite of the ex-Bmpress is composed of ten persons.

The ex Empress Eugénie before she left Paris lor Egypt declared in an interview : Life is hard, but the great thing is courage. I once used the phrase, 'U n'y a rien comme l'audace,' under very trying circumstances, and it gave me courage. Be not cast down. Adversities will come, but what of them. Give courage to others, it is better than money. I am speaking of moral courage, which is a great and lofty virtue. The ethical ride of life should be developed, and then all would be happier. Courage springs from love, and love has been called the greatest thing on
Sir Thomas Lipton arrived at the Savoy Hotel last night.
Among other arrivals at the savoy yesterday evening were Mlle, de Bassano, Comte Primoli, Comte Chary, and M. Pietri.
The Duke and Duchess of Devonshire, who are now in Cairo, expect to be away from England for two months.
The Duke of Devonshire was presented to the Khedive at Abdeen Palace yesterday by Lord Cromer.
Prince Aria el-Dowlat Riza Khan Danish, Persian Ambassador to the Sublime Ottoman Porte, left Alexandria to-day for Constantinople by the Russian packet
The Countess of Lovelace and Sir Edmund Veruey arrived at Port Said yesterday from Malta by the S.S- "City of Corinth," and left by the evening train for Cairo.
Earl and Countess Howe, with Sir Edward and lady Colebrooke, have left London for Egypt and a trip up the Nile m the guests of Sir Ernest Cassel.
The Hon. John Ward will accompany Sir Ernest Cassel's party to Egypt- Mr. Ward, who is now on the Riviera, will join the party at Marseilles to-day.

The latest arrivals at Shepheard's Hotel include Sir Robert and Lady Pullar, Major-General Campbell-Fraser, Baron Pidoll, Baron Pycke de Peteghem, Vicomte de Sapucahy, Oberslentuaut and Mrs. von der Plawitz, Mr. and Mrs. Beeckmann, Mrs. James W. Byrue and family, Mr. and Mrs. Basuardo and family, Mr and Mrs. Marshall P. Wilder, Mr. and Mrs. de Thierry, Baron Drasche, Baron Voi-rensky, Baron de Wecker, etc.

Many large dinner parties are to be given belote the concert, organised by the Comité des Fetes, takes place at the Savoy this evening. Next Saturday's dance promises to be exceptionally successful, nearly all the tables in the restaurant being already engaged.

The Hon. J. W. Riddle, American Diplomats Agent, entertained a party to dinner at the Savoy Restaurant yesterday evening, the guests including M. and Mme. Maskens, Fabricius Pasha and Mme. Fabricius, the Hon. F G Morgan, M. and Mme. de Gorostarzu, M and Mme. Maximoff, Comte Amvabeue, M. and Mme. de Hoeltzke,Comte and Comtesse Antoine de Zogheb, Judge and Mrs. Tuck. Mr. and Mrs. Linooln Tangye have left Maxstoke Castle, Warwickshire, en route 1er Egypt.

Mrs. Ronald Greville has come to Egypt with her father, Mr. McEwan, who has been seriously ill. He was ordered to a warmer climate, and Mrs. Greville at once cancelled all her engagements in order to accompany him.
Mr. George Faber, M.P. for York city, has arrived in Egypt for a stay of some duration, and hopes to return to England to resume his
Parliamentary duties in March. He is accompanied by his wife, who was the youngest daughter of Sir Frederick Graham of Nethberby and Lady Jane Hermione, daughter of the 12th Duke of Somerset.

Mr. Clapcott, the newly-appointed English judge for Assiout Tribunel, has been delegated by the Ministry of Justice for Keneh Tribunal. He is expected to arrive here tomorrow His visits here will he on Sunday and Monday of every week, during the hearing of criminal cases ; on the other days of the week he will be resident at Luxor.
A new branch of the National Bank is to be opened here. The agent, who is an Englishman, has arrived here for the purpose of finding suitable premises.

div.head: COMMISSION MUNICIPALE
div.p: (Communication Officilelle.) Commission municipale seat réunie le 85 janvier 1905, à 4 h. p.m, sous U présideoœ de S.B. Mahmoud pacha Sidky.

Présents : MM. Amb. A. Ralli, vice-président, Ahmed bey Byoub, Ahmed bey Yehia, Hussein bey Riez, A. Cumbo, L Esooffier, P. Fender), P. Glymenopoulo, Maasour bey Youseff, A. de Menasce, 0. Rothaker, A. Padoa bey, Dr J. Schiess bey, T. Suzxarini, Dr G. Valensia, G. Zervudachi, G. Zouro, membres, W. P. Cha-taway, administrateur, 1. Sedky bey, secrétaire.
En ouvrant la séanoe, le Président dit qu'il est assuré d'être l'interprète des sentiments de l'Assemblée entière eu exprimant ses regrets pour le départ do LL. EK Michalla et
Said bey.

Lu services éminents rendus à l'institution municipale par ces deux hauts fonctionnaires et la sympathie qui s'attache à leur personne, auraient avivé davantage ces regrets, si la Commission u'éprouvait en même temps du plaisir pour l'avancement acoordé à l'un et la retraite honorable qui couronne la carrière de l'autre. Lour souvenir restera toujours vivant dans cette Assemblée, qui leur transmet à cette occasion ses vœux les plus sincères.
Après quelques paroles du Vice-Président, l'Assemblée entière s'associe aux sentiments exprimés.
la procès-verbaux de la Commission des 30 novembre, 3 et 21 décembre 1904, sont approuvés.
Mention est laite dé l'envoi à tous les membres du procès-verbal de la Délégation du 3 janvier 1905.
Au aqjet de cette communication, un éohango d idées a lieu relativement à la question du ooutrôle par la Municipalité de la Compagnie du chemin de fer de Ramleh.
Cette question est renvoyée à l'étude du Comité du Contentieux.
Communication est donnée d'une lettre de S.K. le Ministre do l'Intérieur du 18 janvier 1905 inlormant qu'il approuve le budget de la Muqffcipalité pour l'exercice 1905.

Lecture est également donnée d'une lettre du 21 janvier 1905 de SJL le Ministre de l'inté-neur informant que dan» sou opinion, la ques* Uon de la rage doit faire l'objet d'une réglementation générale, et ceci afin d'éviter que sur uue question qui intéresse le pays tout entier, il puisse y avoir une règlementation différente à Alexandrie et dan» les autres villes. C'est dans oet ordre d'idées que 8.E. le Ministre a dès A présent demandé au Comité do Contentieux d'élaborer sur les chions et la prévention de la rage un projet de règlement qui serait applicable A toute l'Egypte.

11 estime qu'il ne saurait dono sanctionner la décision municipale mai* U g plaisir A féliciter la Municipalité poor son initiative en cette matière importante et pour la contribution que ses travaux apportent A l'étude de la queauou par le Gouvernement.

La Commission considérant l'urgence qu'il y a dans la circonstance A adopter des mesures efficaces contre la propagation de la rage, décide d'iusister auprès du Gouvernement pour qu'il veuille bien sanctionner le projet de règlement qu elle lui a soumis.

Dès que le Gouvernement aura promulgué son règlement, la Municipalité pourra ajouter, s'il y a lieu, A celui qu'elle a déjA élaboré, toutes les dispositions nouvelles pour mettre en harmonie les deux règlementations.

Communication est ensuite donnée d'une lettre du 22 Juin de S.K le Ministre de Fin teneur, informant qu'il consent A oe que la Municipalité prenne possession d'un espace de terrain do 45 mètres de profondeur sur 173 da longueur, du domaine de l'hOpital indigène, en laçade de la rue d'Allemagne, pour être trans-tormé en parc.
La Commission remercie le Gouvernement ainsi que M. le Dr Schiess Bey promoteur de cette proposition.

Vu la lettre du 18 janvier de S.E le Ministre des Finances et la correspondance échangée avec F Administration des'chemins de fer, au . sujet de l'élargissement du pont du Gabbari, la Commission émet un avis favorable A la contribution de la Municipalité dans lee dépenses nécessitées par oe travail, mais comme a cette question se rattachent des questions d'alignement et d'expropriation des routes accédant au dit pont, la Commission, avant de prendre une décision définitive, prie les membres de l'Assemblée représentant le Commerce d'Exportation, de se rendre compte de l'importance dos expropriations éventuelles et d'en faire rapport a la Commission.

La Commission prend dbnnaissanoe d'une lettre de M. André, ingéuieur paysagiste, professeur A l'école d'horticulture de Versailles pour l'art des jardins offrant ses services pour l'élaboration d'un projet d'ensemble pour les parcs de la ville, sans engagement de la part de la Municipalité.
L'Assemblée accepte cette proposition. Communication est donnée d'un état préliminaire dos comptes de l'année 1904, accusant un solde disponible de L.B. 31,197.
Cet état sera suivi ultérieurement des développements qu'il comporte.
LÀ Commission approuve les propositions du Comité dos fiuauoea au sujet du classement du personnel.

Elle adopte A ce sqjet la manière de voir dti Comité en oe qui conoerne l'amélioration du système de retraite du personnel municipal, la suppression des indemnités fixes de déplacement, l'interdiction aux ingénieurs de la Municipalité d'accepter des occupations au dehors pour compte des tiers.
La Commission porte lee appointements de MM. Plot bey et Breocia, respectivement A LK 480 et 480 par an.
Une question relative aux membres provisoires de la Délégation, sera réglée A l'oooaeicra de l'élaboration du règlement intérieur.
La Commission approuve un état d'estimation des exoédents et emprises nécessaires Dour le redoneaent dm voies publiques.

div.head: EXPORT MANIFESTS.
div.p: For LONDON, by the S.S. "Sapho", sailed on the 14th January :
Barker & Co., 985 tons cotton seed
Carver Bros. & Coy. Ltd, 819
Bebrend & Co., 500 tons cotton sced, 2,267 bags sugar
Cugini Viterbo, 500 bags sugar
Bank of Egypt, 575 packages oil cake
